policies.name: Identification and Authentication Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing authentication mechanisms and feedback obscuring requirements
policies.rationale: NIST 03.05.11 requires obscuring authentication feedback during the authentication process, which necessitates formal policy guidance on acceptable methods

procedures.name: Authentication Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for configuring authentication interfaces to obscure feedback (asterisks for passwords, limited-time display, etc.)
procedures.rationale: Control requires implementing obscuring mechanisms; procedure documents how to configure systems to display asterisks or obscure passwords after limited time

procedures.name: Authentication System Testing Procedure
procedures.description: Process for testing authentication interfaces to verify feedback is properly obscured across all platforms (desktop, mobile, web)
procedures.rationale: Discussion mentions different threat levels for large monitors vs small mobile displays; testing ensures appropriate obscuring methods are applied

executionEvidence.name: Authentication Interface Configuration Screenshots
executionEvidence.description: Screenshots showing: login screens with password fields displaying asterisks, mobile authentication screens with appropriate feedback obscuring, web application login forms with masked input
executionEvidence.frequency: Annual (or when authentication systems are updated)
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates technical implementation of feedback obscuring across all authentication interfaces; annual verification ensures configurations remain in place

executionEvidence.name: Authentication System Testing Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: systems tested, feedback obscuring methods verified (asterisks, timeout-based obscuring), platforms tested (Windows, macOS, iOS, Android, web browsers), test results, tester signatures
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion requires selecting obscuring means based on platform; annual testing verifies proper implementation across all platforms

executionEvidence.name: Authentication System Configuration Standards
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: technical configuration standards for login screens, password field settings (masked input enabled), timeout values for limited-time display, browser-specific configurations
executionEvidence.rationale: Provides audit trail of organizational standards for implementing authentication feedback obscuring

operationalActivities: Configure all authentication interfaces to obscure password entry with asterisks or dots
Implement timeout-based feedback obscuring where temporary display is needed
Test authentication interfaces across all platforms (desktop, mobile, web) for proper feedback obscuring
Review authentication system configurations annually to verify feedback obscuring remains enabled
Update authentication standards when new systems or platforms are deployed

policies.name: Identification and Authentication Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing authenticator lifecycle management including distribution, protection, and revocation
policies.rationale: NIST 03.05.12 requires comprehensive authenticator management spanning initial distribution through revocation, necessitating formal policy framework

policies.name: Authenticator Protection Policy
policies.description: Policy defining requirements for protecting authenticator content from unauthorized disclosure and modification
policies.rationale: Control requirement 03.05.12.f explicitly requires protecting authenticator content; policy establishes organizational standards for storage and transmission protection

procedures.name: Initial Authenticator Distribution Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for: verifying recipient identity, establishing initial authenticator content, distributing authenticators securely, documenting distribution
procedures.rationale: Control requirements 03.05.12.a and 03.05.12.b require identity verification and establishing initial content during distribution

procedures.name: Authenticator Lifecycle Management Procedure
procedures.description: Process for: changing default authenticators at first use, periodic authenticator refresh schedule, handling lost/compromised/damaged authenticators, revoking authenticators upon termination
procedures.rationale: Control requirements 03.05.12.c, 03.05.12.d, and 03.05.12.e require administrative procedures for entire authenticator lifecycle

procedures.name: Authenticator Storage and Protection Procedure
procedures.description: Process for: storing passwords in cryptographically protected form, transmitting authenticators over encrypted channels, protecting cryptographic devices and certificates, handling biometric templates
procedures.rationale: Control requirement 03.05.12.f requires protecting authenticator content; discussion mentions passwords stored in hashed/encrypted formats

executionEvidence.name: Authenticator Distribution Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: recipient identity verification method (ID check, manager approval), authenticator type issued (password, certificate, token, badge), initial content established, distribution date, recipient signature acknowledging receipt
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates execution of 03.05.12.a and 03.05.12.b requirements for identity verification and initial content establishment

executionEvidence.name: Default Authenticator Change Logs
executionEvidence.description: System logs showing: temporary passwords expired on first use, default certificates replaced before production use, system accounts with default credentials changed, timestamps of changes
executionEvidence.rationale: Proves compliance with 03.05.12.d requirement to change default authenticators at first use

executionEvidence.name: Authenticator Refresh/Rotation Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: passwords changed per organization-defined frequency (e.g., 90 days), certificates renewed before expiration, cryptographic keys rotated, authenticator refresh events triggered (role changes, suspected compromise), completion dates
executionEvidence.frequency: Per organization-defined schedule (typically 90 days for passwords, annually for certificates)
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates 03.05.12.e requirement to change/refresh authenticators at defined frequency or when specific events occur

executionEvidence.name: Lost/Compromised Authenticator Incident Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: incident report filed, old authenticator revoked/disabled, new authenticator issued, user re-verified, completion date, approvals
executionEvidence.rationale: Proves 03.05.12.c requirement for procedures handling lost, compromised, or damaged authenticators

executionEvidence.name: Authenticator Revocation Logs
executionEvidence.description: System logs showing: authenticators disabled upon termination, access revoked within required timeframe, group/role account authenticators changed when membership changes, certificates revoked, physical badges deactivated
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates 03.05.12.c revocation procedures and supports related control 03.01.01 for account management

executionEvidence.name: Authenticator Protection Audit Evidence
executionEvidence.description: Evidence showing: password hashing algorithms used (bcrypt, PBKDF2, Argon2), database encryption status for password stores, TLS/HTTPS enforcement for password transmission, key vault configurations for certificate storage, access controls on authenticator repositories
executionEvidence.rationale: Proves 03.05.12.f requirement to protect authenticator content from unauthorized disclosure and modification; NIST discussion explicitly mentions hashed/encrypted password storage

executionEvidence.name: Authenticator Inventory
executionEvidence.description: Comprehensive inventory showing: all authenticator types in use (passwords, certificates, tokens, biometrics, badges), systems using each authenticator type, authenticator lifecycle status, refresh/expiration dates, responsible owners
executionEvidence.rationale: Supports overall authenticator management requirement; enables tracking of all authenticators subject to protection and lifecycle management

operationalActivities: Verify identity of individuals before distributing authenticators (check government ID, verify with manager)
Establish initial authenticator content for new accounts (temporary password, certificate, token)
Distribute authenticators securely and obtain recipient acknowledgment
Force change of temporary/default authenticators on first use
Refresh passwords every 90 days (or organization-defined frequency)
Renew certificates before expiration
Rotate cryptographic keys per key management policy
Handle lost/compromised authenticator incidents within 24 hours
Revoke authenticators immediately upon employee termination
Change group/role account authenticators when membership changes
Store passwords using strong hashing algorithms (bcrypt, Argon2)
Transmit passwords only over TLS/HTTPS encrypted channels
Protect certificate private keys in secure key stores
Maintain audit logs of all authenticator lifecycle events
Review authenticator protection mechanisms quarterly
